News Flash

City of Modesto Notice of Funding Availability (NOFA) for FY 26-27

Public Service GrantsThe City of Modesto solicits proposals for eligible public service programs through its Community Development Block Grant and Emergency Solutions Grant programs annually.  Program PurposeThe purpose of this program is to solicit program proposals from non-profit, 501 (c)(3) and/or eligible service providers for the purpose of awarding Community Development Block Grant and Emergency Solutions Grant public service funding to directly serve low-income families and individuals within the City of Modesto. Federal regulations for direct services funded under this program limits funding to new or programs that can demonstrate program expansion.2026-2027 Public Service Program Calendar of EventsFebruary 6, 2026Notice of Funding Availability Open for Public ReviewNeighborly Application Portal Opens for ApplicationsPlease review the Technical Assistance PDF linked below for more information regarding the NOFAFebruary 20, 2026Virtual Office Hours will be held via TEAMS to answer any questions that applicants may have prior to application submission.  Office Hours will be held 2:pm to 3:30pm on February 20th, 2026.Meeting Link: Join the meeting nowMeeting ID: 234 418 814 923 78Passcode: 77oJ92svFebruary 27, 2026, at 4:00 pmDeadline to submit FY 2026-2027 Grant Applications via Neighborly Software on the below link.Due no later than 4:00 p.m. No Exceptions.Additional Important Information can be found on the City of Modesto Website under Notices of Funding (NOFA).  If you have any questions, please contact: City of Modesto Community Development Division, 1010 10th Street, Suite 3100, Modesto CA 95351Call (209) 577-5211
Community Development
Posted on February 06, 2026

City of Modesto Launches New Platform called City View, Connecting Data to Our Community

Modesto, CA, February 17, 2026 - The City of Modesto is taking a major step towards government transparency, accountability and community engagement with the launch of City View, a new open data platform going live February 17, 2026.City View provides residents, businesses, and community organizations with easy access to the most up-to-date data that informs the decision-making process for our City. The platform creates a centralized hub for community members to explore key performance indicators (KPIs) and track the impact of City programs and services. Hosted by Tyler Technologies, City View transforms complex government data into interactive charts, dashboards and visuals that can be accessed from any web browser or smartphone.  Phase 1 of City View will focus on Measure H, the 1% local sales tax approved by voters in November 2022 and implemented on April 1, 2023. Community members will be able to track programs and projects approved through the annual Measure H spending plans that have been approved by City Council. Ensuring visibility into how Measure H funds are impacting our City and telling the story behind the numbers that are used in the decision-making process.Phase 2 will expand the platform to citywide programs and encompass all other funds in the organization. For example, funds like Surface Transportation, Water, and Wastewater will showcase its open data behind the work being done in the community to improve City streets, ensure residents have clean drinking water and proper sanitation services.City View is part of the Cityâ€™s broader Smart City Strategy, focused on efficiency, data culture, and community well-being. Modesto Receives Prestigious Awards for Financial Management

Modesto, CA, December 8, 2025 – The City of Modesto is being recognized for commitment to excellence and meeting the highest standards of government financial reporting and budgeting by the Government Finance Officers Association (GFOA). The GFOA presented Modesto with three recognitions for the fiscal year that ended on June 30, 2024:The Certificate of Achievement for Excellence in Financial Reporting for the City’s Annual Comprehensive Financial Report that is transparent and in full disclosure above and beyond the minimal requirements.The Award for Outstanding Achievement in Popular Annual Financial Reporting (PAFR Award) recognizes the high-quality summary report of the City’s financial information is presented in a way that is readily accessible and easily understandable by the general public.  The Distinguished Budget Presentation Award for an effective budget presentation that meets the highest standards for how well the City’s budget serves as a policy document, financial plan, operations guide, and a communications device for the community.The City of Modesto has secured the prestigious Triple Crown designation from the GOFA for all three recognitions. This is the fifth year in a row that the City as achieved this reputable designation.  This is a reflection of our City Councils dedication to being fiscally responsible while meeting the essential needs of our community and making lasting decisions that enhance the quality of life for all residents. “Responsible budgeting is at the center of effective leadership for Modesto,” says Mayor Sue Zwahlen.  “I know our City Council is committed to making informed, and responsible decisions with taxpayer dollars.”  These recognitions acknowledge the City’s strategic and proactive approach to financial management of the City’s budget.  From maintaining safe streets, and City parks, to investing in affordable housing and economic development, Modesto is demonstrating strong financial integrity for our community today and for the City’s future. In celebration of this recognition, there will be a presentation at the City Council meeting on December 9, 2025.View the City of Modesto Popular Annual Financial Report.Press Release ContactSonya SeveroPublic Relations and Legislative Affairs Manager209-497-0075Email Sonya Severo

Posted on December 08, 2025

City Councilâ€™s â€œYesâ€ Vote Signals New Path Forward for Downtown Streets Team Participants

Modesto, CA, October 14, 2025 – The City of Modesto is ensuring the mission of the Downtown Streets team continues with a “yes” vote by the City Council, approving a proposed Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with United Way of Stanislaus County for a partnership with the Modesto Gospel Mission.  With the Downtown Streets Team slated to cease operations on October 31, 2025, the transition to United Way and the Modesto Gospel Mission will make sure there is no service gap for people rebuilding their lives out of homelessness.  This is a meaningful shift for a service that has been impactful for our communities’ most vulnerable residents and their contributions towards making Modesto Mo’Beautiful.The United Way will serve as the fiscal agent overseeing a funding allocation not to exceed $1,250,000. It will also work towards developing a sustainability plan to support funding the operation for the future.   The City will coordinate efforts with the Stanislaus Community Foundation, and other community partners to identify additional grant and funding opportunities to support the program beyond the first year of the program.  The funding sources for this initiative include:State Grant: $1,050,000Private Contribution: $150,000Litter Abatement Fund: $50,000“The United Way is proud to partner with the City of Modesto and Modesto Gospel Mission to support our unhoused neighbors. Building on the strong foundation laid by Downtown Streets Team, this program provides meaningful work, connection to vital services, and a pathway to stability and dignity for people in our community,” says Keristofer Seryani, Chief Executive Officer of the United Way of Stanislaus County.The Modesto Gospel Mission will operate the program, ensuring essential outreach and employment support for up to 68 participants. They will provide blight abatement services in our community while obtaining necessary work experience and earning an hourly wage. The goal is to begin offering wrap-around support services to program participants on November 1, 2025, they will support participants as they navigate through the barriers to housing, mental health issues, substance use treatment services and accessing additional public benefits. “The Modesto Gospel Mission is honored and excited to continue the important work of the Downtown Streets Team, says Jason Conway, Chief Executive Officer of the Modesto Gospel Mission. “This program provides meaningful employment opportunities and case management for individuals experiencing homelessness while helping keep our city clean and beautiful. We look forward to partnering with the City of Modesto to bring hope, dignity, and purpose to our neighbors through this transformative effort.”Although the City was disappointed to hear of the closing of the Downtown Streets team in Modesto, the City once again relied on community collaboration to keep the doors open to self-sufficiency and hope for people who need it the most, a guiding principle of the Camp2Home initiative. Press Release ContactSonya SeveroPublic Relations and Legislative Affairs Manager209-497-0075Email Sonya Severo

  • City of Modesto Notice of Funding Availability (NOFA) for FY 26-27

    Public Service Grants

    The City of Modesto solicits proposals for eligible public service programs through its Community Development Block Grant and Emergency Solutions Grant programs annually.  

    Program Purpose

    The purpose of this program is to solicit program proposals from non-profit, 501 (c)(3) and/or eligible service providers for the purpose of awarding Community Development Block Grant and Emergency Solutions Grant public service funding to directly serve low-income families and individuals within the City of Modesto. Federal regulations for direct services funded under this program limits funding to new or programs that can demonstrate program expansion.

    2026-2027 Public Service Program Calendar of Events

    February 6, 2026

      • Notice of Funding Availability Open for Public Review
      • Neighborly Application Portal Opens for Applications
      • Please review the Technical Assistance PDF linked below for more information regarding the NOFA

    February 20, 2026

      • Virtual Office Hours will be held via TEAMS to answer any questions that applicants may have prior to application submission.  
      • Office Hours will be held 2:pm to 3:30pm on February 20th, 2026.
      • Meeting Link: Join the meeting now
      • Meeting ID: 234 418 814 923 78
      • Passcode: 77oJ92sv

    February 27, 2026, at 4:00 pm

      • Deadline to submit FY 2026-2027 Grant Applications via Neighborly Software on the below link.
      • Due no later than 4:00 p.m. No Exceptions.

    Additional Important Information can be found on the City of Modesto Website under Notices of Funding (NOFA).  If you have any questions, please contact: 

    • City of Modesto Community Development Division, 1010 10th Street, Suite 3100, Modesto CA 95351
    • Call (209) 577-5211

  • Groundbreaking Ceremony for the Center for Human Services Behavioral Health Outpatient Center

    The City of Modesto is thrilled to announce todayâ€™s groundbreaking ceremony for the Center for Human Services (CHS) Behavioral Health Outpatient Center. This event marks a significant milestone in Modesto's ongoing efforts to develop a comprehensive system of care for homeless youth through a robust public-private partnership.
     
    A Model of Innovation and Excellence
    Modesto's innovative approach has earned the city the prestigious California Cities Helen Putnam Award for Excellence in Housing Programs and Innovations. In partnership with CHS, Modesto has created a coordinated system of care for youth experiencing homelessness, which includes the Youth Navigation Center (YNC) with 48 low-barrier shelter and transitional housing beds. Additionally, an underutilized commercial property has been converted into 14 permanent supportive housing units, establishing a dedicated housing pipeline with wrap-around supportive services for homeless youth.
     
    Sustainable Funding for Long-Term Impact
    As part of Modesto's strategic priority to protect and expand investments to prevent and reduce homelessness, CHS has secured sustainable funding to support individuals experiencing, or at risk of, homelessness. This funding strengthens state and local partnerships, connecting individuals with the care they need through coordinated care systems that provide access to comprehensive services, including mental health and substance use treatment.
     
    Significant Grant to Enhance Services
    CHS successfully applied for a $5,000,000 grant as part of Governor Gavin Newsomâ€™s Master Plan for Kidsâ€™ Mental Health. This grant will enable the YNC to expand mental health and substance use treatment services, reaching an estimated 1,400 youth in Stanislaus County.
     
    Addressing the Trauma of Homelessness
    According to the US Department of Health and Human Services, homelessness can profoundly affect a youthâ€™s development. Homeless youth often face higher rates of emotional, behavioral, and health problems, along with academic challenges. The YNCâ€™s â€œone-stop shopâ€ approach consolidates multiple services under one roof, providing immediate access to essential services for youth in crisis. The introduction of Coordinated Entry and Assessment entry points for youth is a critical innovation that did not previously exist in the community.
     
    Ensuring Long-Term Success
    This partnership and its innovative approach to housing solutions ensure the programâ€™s operation for the next 55 years. The YNC's youth-centric programs, including housing and youth-driven policy boards, are designed to identify barriers and expand access to youth housing in innovative and result-driven ways.
     
    To learn more, we invite you to explore the Western City Magazine â€œModesto creates a countywide system of care for youth experiencing homelessnessâ€ article.

  • City of Modesto Launches New Platform called City View, Connecting Data to Our Community

    Modesto, CA, February 17, 2026 - The City of Modesto is taking a major step towards government transparency, accountability and community engagement with the launch of City View, a new open data platform going live February 17, 2026.

    City View provides residents, businesses, and community organizations with easy access to the most up-to-date data that informs the decision-making process for our City. The platform creates a centralized hub for community members to explore key performance indicators (KPIs) and track the impact of City programs and services. Hosted by Tyler Technologies, City View transforms complex government data into interactive charts, dashboards and visuals that can be accessed from any web browser or smartphone.  

    Phase 1 of City View will focus on Measure H, the 1% local sales tax approved by voters in November 2022 and implemented on April 1, 2023. Community members will be able to track programs and projects approved through the annual Measure H spending plans that have been approved by City Council. Ensuring visibility into how Measure H funds are impacting our City and telling the story behind the numbers that are used in the decision-making process.

    Phase 2 will expand the platform to citywide programs and encompass all other funds in the organization. For example, funds like Surface Transportation, Water, and Wastewater will showcase its open data behind the work being done in the community to improve City streets, ensure residents have clean drinking water and proper sanitation services.

    City View is part of the Cityâ€™s broader Smart City Strategy, focused on efficiency, data culture, and community well-being. Enhancing the Cityâ€™s ability to provide crucial information to the public as it continues to work towards improved transparency and engagement with the residents it serves.

    Download the press release (pdf).

    Posted on February 17, 2026

  • City of Modesto Receives a National Honor with the Audrey Nelson Community Development Award

    Modesto, CA, January 28, 2026 â€“ On February 6, 2026, the City of Modesto will be one of seven recipients of the National Community Development Association (NCDA) Audrey Nelson Community Development Award. Modesto is being recognized for Jennyâ€™s Place, a permanent supportive housing project that provides support for individuals and youth experiencing homelessness.  The recognition highlights the Cityâ€™s ability to align community collaboration with federal funding to address the needs of residents rebuilding their lives out of homelessness.   

    â€œBy maximizing our resources and leveraging strong partnerships in our community, Modesto has been able to turn a once underutilized motel, into 54 housing units providing individuals with opportunities to build a sustainable and meaningful future,â€ says Jessica Hill, Director of Community and Economic Development for the City of Modesto.

    In partnership with Upholdings, Stanislaus County Behavioral Health and Recovery Services, and Center for Human Services, and with capital funding from the City of Modesto, Health Plan of San Joaquin, State of California HomeKey Program, and Stanislaus County Community System of Care, the motel conversion began in early 2024 and opened its doors to hope in May of 2025.

    Jennyâ€™s Place has a dedicated focus on youth experiencing homelessness; along with housing, they provide coordinated case management services including peer support activities, mental health care, and healthy community connections building on an existing continuum of care for youth experiencing homelessness in partnership with Center for Human Services.  

    "Jenny's Place is for young people in our community who need support when they are at risk and face barriers to survival," says City of Modesto Mayor, Sue Zwahlen. "Since opening, Jenny's Place has served 42 youth, offering a safe environment, where they can work on their independence while knowing help is available if they need it."

    The NCDA is a non-partisan national non-profit association comprised of more than 500 local governments across the country that administer federally supported community development, affordable housing, and economic development programs through the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.  

    The NCDA established the Audrey Nelson Community Development Award in 1987 to recognize and honor communities which exemplify outstanding achievement in service to residents, families, and neighborhoods through innovative and impactful uses of Community Development Block Grant and HOME funds that address the needs of families, homes, and neighborhoods.  

    Press Release Audrey Nelson Announcement 2026

  • Modesto Receives Prestigious Awards for Financial Management

    Modesto, CA, December 8, 2025 – The City of Modesto is being recognized for commitment to excellence and meeting the highest standards of government financial reporting and budgeting by the Government Finance Officers Association (GFOA). The GFOA presented Modesto with three recognitions for the fiscal year that ended on June 30, 2024:

    • The Certificate of Achievement for Excellence in Financial Reporting for the City’s Annual Comprehensive Financial Report that is transparent and in full disclosure above and beyond the minimal requirements.
    • The Award for Outstanding Achievement in Popular Annual Financial Reporting (PAFR Award) recognizes the high-quality summary report of the City’s financial information is presented in a way that is readily accessible and easily understandable by the general public.  
    • The Distinguished Budget Presentation Award for an effective budget presentation that meets the highest standards for how well the City’s budget serves as a policy document, financial plan, operations guide, and a communications device for the community.

    The City of Modesto has secured the prestigious Triple Crown designation from the GOFA for all three recognitions. This is the fifth year in a row that the City as achieved this reputable designation.  

    This is a reflection of our City Councils dedication to being fiscally responsible while meeting the essential needs of our community and making lasting decisions that enhance the quality of life for all residents. 

    “Responsible budgeting is at the center of effective leadership for Modesto,” says Mayor Sue Zwahlen.  “I know our City Council is committed to making informed, and responsible decisions with taxpayer dollars.”  

    These recognitions acknowledge the City’s strategic and proactive approach to financial management of the City’s budget.  From maintaining safe streets, and City parks, to investing in affordable housing and economic development, Modesto is demonstrating strong financial integrity for our community today and for the City’s future. 

    In celebration of this recognition, there will be a presentation at the City Council meeting on December 9, 2025.

    View the City of Modesto Popular Annual Financial Report.

  • The City Announces Great Progress in Keeping Professional Baseball in Modesto

    Modesto, CA, September 12, 2025 - The City Council recently approved an agreement with Main Street Modesto, LLC, a Pioneer League affiliate, for a team to play at John Thurman Field. The new team’s first pitch will be in 2026. 

    Last year, the City was disappointed that negotiations with the Seattle Mariners did not lead to a resolution to keep the Modesto Nuts in our community.  Although the discussions did not reach the successful result that we had hoped for, the City recognized that baseball was too important to Modesto to let it go.

    The City energetically explored various opportunities to enhance access to affordable sports and entertainment options for families in Modesto, which led to this new partnership with Main Street to bring a Pioneer League team to John Thurman Field.

    At the City Council meeting, Mayor Sue Zwahlen said, “this is really exciting, that we will continue to have baseball!” 

    This long-term lease agreement is a significant step forward in the City’s commitment to ensuring John Thurman Field continues to serve as a home for professional baseball and community events.  Once again, the City focused on longevity and sustainability for a successful partnership.

    “Modesto and John Thurman Field have a long and storied history of hosting our nation’s pastime, and I am so excited not merely to continue that tradition but to build and improve on it with the most fun, affordable, and family-friendly brand of entertainment this community has ever seen,” said new team owner Dave Heller.

    This community-driven decision supports the Council’s strategic priorities by advancing a pro-growth economic development strategy that focuses on downtown, sports, and entertainment, continuing to build Modesto as a regional destination in California.

    “On behalf of all the member clubs of the Pioneer Baseball League, I am so very pleased and excited to have Modesto join our wonderful league,” said Pioneer Baseball League President Mike Shapiro. 

    The City of Modesto will be hosting a press event soon with Main Street Modesto, LLC, and we invite the community to join as a new inning for baseball begins in our community.  

    Download a PDF of the Press Release

    For more information, contact:

    Sonya SeveroPublic Relations and Legislative Affairs Manager209-497-0075Email Sonya Severo

  • City of Modesto Unlocks the Doors to Stability at Grace Gardens

    Modesto, CA, August 1, 2025 - The City of Modesto bridges the gap between despair and opportunity for people experiencing homelessness with the grand opening of Grace Gardens.  Located at 1530 Owens Drive, Grace Gardens is a non-congregate shelter that will support moving people into a stable environment as they rebuild their lives out of homelessness. 

    A new beginning starts at the Grand Opening; event details are as follows:

    • Date: Friday August 15th from 9:30 am â€“ 11:00 am
    • Location: Modesto Gospel Mission, 1400 Yosemite Blvd, Modesto, CA

    Grace Gardens is a City of Modesto bridge housing project that will serve both men and women that are referred by the Modesto Gospel Mission.  The residents will be assigned case managers and will be referred to service providers who will focus on connecting them to income, public benefits, health services, and other supportive services, lifting them up out of uncertainty and into possibility.  

    The City of Modesto developed a partnership with Stanislaus County Affordable Housing Corporation (StanCo) for project management, design, and construction oversight.  To help make this project sustainable, the City is collaborating with the Modesto Gospel Mission, who is the property owner, to serve as the service provider, site operator, and property manager for Grace Gardens. 

    The Modesto Gospel Missionâ€™s proven experience and innovation in providing services for people in the community will lend itself towards long-term outcomes and sustainable solutions for the people being served in Modesto. 

    â€œGrace Gardens helps our people by providing a safe, supportive environment where they can thrive,â€ says Mayor Sue Zwahlen.

    The 12-unit project at Grace Gardens includes one Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) unit. Residents will be able to access food, laundry, and shower services at the Modesto Gospel Mission main campus.  

    The total budget for development of Grace Gardens is approximately $527,482 and the cost includes one-time infrastructure, unit acquisition, and unit assembly, which is funded by Measure H.  The State also awarded the City approximately $5.7 million in Encampment Resolution Funds (ERF), of which approximately $1.5 million, will be dedicated to the ongoing operating expenses of Grace Gardens.

    â€œFor Modesto, Grace Gardens bridge housing stands as a beacon of hope, offering shelter and dignity to those experiencing homelessness. Together, we cultivate a community where every individual can find solace, rebuild their lives, and flourish in a nurturing environment,â€ says Jason Conway, Chief Executive Officer of the Modesto Gospel Mission.

    For more information, contact:

    Sonya SeveroPublic Relations and Legislative Affairs Manager209-497-0075Email Sonya Severo

    Newsroom
    Posted on August 06, 2025

  • A New Inning in Baseball Begins in Modesto

    Modesto, CA, September 16, 2025 - The Modesto City Council last week approved an agreement with Main Street Modesto, LLC, for a new Pioneer Baseball League team to play at John Thurman Field. The new team, which has not yet been named, is expected to start play when the Pioneer League’s 87th season kicks off in May, 2026. The team is planning to hold a “Name the Team” contest and plans to invite fans to suggest a new name for the Modesto club.

    The Pioneer Baseball League is one of four MLB Partner Leagues and is uniquely focused on developing young future Major Leaguers. As a player development league, PBL players may only have up to three years of professional experience.  Since 2021, more than 75 PBL players have had their contracts purchased by MLB clubs.

    Dave Heller, the owner of the new Modesto club, also owns a Pioneer League team in Billings, MT, as well as two affiliated teams, the Wilmington Blue Rocks, Advanced-A affiliate of the Washington Nationals, and the Quad Cities River Bandits, Advanced-A affiliate of the Kansas City Royals. Heller’s company, Main Street Baseball, earned Ballpark Digest’s coveted “Minor League Baseball Organization of the Year” award – one of the industry’s highest honors. His Quad Cities team, the River Bandits, was named Ballpark Digest’s 2021 “Team of the Year” and one of Baseball America’s “Most Accomplished Franchises of the 2010s.” That club remains the only club in Midwest League history to win four championships in 10 seasons (2011-2021).

    "From our renowned candy drops to our tattoo nights, giveaways, and numerous promotions, we intend to have fun, win games, and create lasting memories for people of all ages,” said new team owner Dave Heller.  “We're thrilled to be here and to build on Modesto’s great baseball tradition with our unique brand of fantastic, fun, affordable family-friendly entertainment. I can't wait until our season opener next May!"

    “The Pioneer League remains baseball’s foremost player development league and provides extraordinary, affordable fan experiences in all our local communities,” added Pioneer League President Mike Shapiro. “In 2025, we attracted over 1 million fans to our charming ballparks throughout the Mountain States and California, and we look forward to bringing our exciting and fun brand of baseball to Modesto and other new communities in California over the next few years.”

    To welcome Main Street Baseball and the Pioneer Baseball League to the City of Modesto, the City will host a press event on September 18, 2025.

    Press Event details:

    Date: September 18, 2025 

    Time: 10:30 am 

    Location: In front of City Hall at 1010 10th Street

     

    Agenda for the media briefing: 

    1.  Opening Remarks, Sonya Severo, City of Modesto

    2. Announcement, Mayor Sue Zwahlen 

    3. Mike Shapiro, Pioneer Baseball League President 

    4. Dave Heller, Team Owner

    5. Closing Remarks, Mayor Sue Zwahlen

    Download the PDF version of this announcement.

    For more information, contact:

    Sonya SeveroPublic Relations and Legislative Affairs Manager209-497-0075Email Sonya Severo

    Expected to be completed by December 2026.

    Traffic Impacts

    • 9th Street from Carpenter Road to L Street

    River Trunk Pump Station 

    Project Status

    Expected to be completed by June 2029.

    Traffic Impacts

    Full closure to all traffic including emergency vehicles. Expected to reopen June 15, 2026.

    • Westbound Tuolumne Boulevard Closed at Bridge Access to Northbound Highway 99 Only
    • Eastbound Tuolumne Boulevard Closed at Bridge Access to Southbound Highway 99 Only
    • Neece Drive Closed to Through Traffic from Tuolumne Boulevard to Fairway Drive

    Please see the City's website for the detour plan and updates: Modestogov.com/3217/River-Trunk-Pump-Station-Project

    Motorists are advised to drive slowly with caution and use alternate routes when possible.

Tuolumne River Regional Park News

1 news item

  • Tuolumne River Regional Park (TRRP) Public Outreach

    The Tuolumne River Regional Park is a large 500-acre park being developed along the seven-mile stretch of the Tuolumne River traversing through the City of Modesto. The river park is an underutilized natural resource with an abundance of recreational and economic opportunities to create a dynamic regional recreation destination.

    The Tuolumne River Regional Park Commission and Citizen Advisory Committee is completing a park master plan update to explore options to develop new hiking trails, river rafting facilities, river beach restoration, picnic areas, mountain biking trails, disc golf courses, adventure climbing/zipline courses and much more! 

    Take part in a survey to help us understand how you currently use the park, and what improvements you would to see made to the park. 

    Participate and learn more about the Tuolumne River Regional Park Master Plan Update on our website.  

    Project Contact

    Ken PetersonParks Planning and Development 209-571-5573Email Ken Peterson

    Tuolumne River Regional Park News
    Posted on June 16, 2023
